G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore falls within the jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the cause of action arose in Berkshire County and the Property where the incident occurred is located in Berkshire County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of land owes a duty to all lawful entrants, including those lawfully on adjacent public sidewalks, to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances to prevent foreseeable harm arising from conditions on the property.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of land owes a duty to all lawful entrants, including those lawfully on adjacent public sidewalks, to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances to prevent foreseeable harm arising from conditions on the property.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The provided text is only a concurring opinion excerpt, and it does not discuss duties owed to persons on adjacent public sidewalks or clearly articulate the scope of duty to all lawful entrants. It mainly criticizes continued reliance on entrant classifications (especially trespassers) and references broader negligence principles. Without the majority’s discussion of scope of duty, this excerpt does not itself establish that owners owe a duty to lawful entrants on adjacent sidewalks to act reasonably regarding conditions on their property.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Richmond v. Warren Inst. for Sav., 307 M.raw_text: Richmond v. Warren Inst. for Sav., 307 Mass. 483, 485–86 (1940)
Richmond v. Warren Inst. for Sav., 307 M.proposition: Massachusetts has long recognized that a landowner must exercise reasonable care to prevent harm to persons on adjoining public ways arising from dangerous conditions on the land, including trees.
Richmond v. Warren Inst. for Sav., 307 M.case_name: Richmond v. Warren Institution for Savings
Richmond v. Warren Inst. for Sav., 307 M.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landlord’s duty regarding obstructions (a bicycle) in an interior common stairway of an apartment building and whether a safety statute creates or evidences a civil duty between landlord and tenant. It does not address duties of landowners to persons on *adjoining public ways* or dangerous conditions such as trees affecting those ways. The proposition about obligations toward public ways and trees is unrelated to the issues decided in this opinion.
Richmond v. Warren Inst. for Sav., 307 M.relevant_excerpt: “There is at common law, in the absence of special agreement, no duty on the part of a landlord to see that articles not part of the building are not left on common stairways by persons other than himself or his agents or employees. His duty relates to the condition of the premises themselves as compared to their condition when the tenancy began.”

United Elec. Light Co. v. Deliso Constr..raw_text: United Elec. Light Co. v. Deliso Constr. Co., 315 Mass. 313, 317–18 (1943)
United Elec. Light Co. v. Deliso Constr..proposition: Massachusetts has long recognized that a landowner must exercise reasonable care to prevent harm to persons on adjoining public ways arising from dangerous conditions on the land, including trees.
United Elec. Light Co. v. Deliso Constr..case_name: United Electric Light Co. v. Deliso Construction Co.
United Elec. Light Co. v. Deliso Constr..support_reasoning: The case deals with conflicts between two lawful underground users of a public way (a utility and a sewer contractor) and analyzes liability in trespass and nuisance for projecting grout into another’s structures. It does not address duties of a landowner to persons on adjoining public ways, nor does it discuss trees or analogous natural conditions on abutting land. The proposition concerns abutting landowner obligations to travelers on public ways, which is outside the scope of this opinion’s holding and reasoning.
United Elec. Light Co. v. Deliso Constr..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff and the defendant were each lawfully occupying a portion of the underground area of a public way, and the duties owed by one to the other were in the main no different than if they occupied adjoining parcels on the surface of the land. … The projection of the grout upon the plaintiff’s property could be found to have arisen from an unreasonable use of the land occupied by the defendant and to have constituted a wrong toward the plaintiff.”

Ponticas v. K.M.S. Invs., 331 N.W.2d 907.proposition: A landowner has at least a duty to take reasonable steps when there is actual or constructive notice that a tree or its limbs present an unreasonable risk of harm to persons on a public sidewalk or way.
Ponticas v. K.M.S. Invs., 331 N.W.2d 907.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is only a one-line concurrence stating agreement with another justice’s dissent and contains no discussion of landowner duties, trees, or sidewalk safety. It does not articulate or adopt any rule about a landowner’s duty regarding trees posing risks to persons on public ways. Therefore, as given, this citation does not support the claimed proposition.
Ponticas v. K.M.S. Invs., 331 N.W.2d 907.relevant_excerpt:
"WAHL, Justice,
concurring.
I concur in the dissent of Justice Scott."

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care under all the circumstances to maintain the tree and its overhanging branches in a reasonably safe condition with respect to pedestrians using the public sidewalk adjacent to the Property.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.support_reasoning: The case concerns the duty owed by landowners to an adult trespasser injured on their land, not a duty with respect to pedestrians on an adjacent public sidewalk. The majority opinion explicitly reaffirms the common-law rule that, as to adult trespassers, the only duty is to refrain from willful, wanton, or reckless conduct, and it does not impose or discuss a general duty of reasonable care to maintain conditions (such as trees or overhanging branches) in a reasonably safe condition for passersby. Thus it does not support the stated proposition about a duty of reasonable care owed to sidewalk pedestrians.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.relevant_excerpt: "The traditional rule in this Commonwealth is that a trespasser is entitled to no greater duty of care from one with a right of control over land (typically the landowner) than that he refrain from wilful, wanton or reckless disregard for the trespasser's safety. … In Mounsey, we held that the standard of due care applied to all lawful entrants. … We expressly excluded trespassers from this rule. … We continue to perceive that significant difference and we recognize now, as we did then, that any legal duty owed by a landowner to an entrant upon his land finds its source in existing social values and customs."

Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.raw_text: Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, such a long‑standing, open, and obvious defect gives rise to constructive notice and a duty to act.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.support_reasoning: The case discusses when circumstantial evidence of a defect’s condition is sufficient to infer that it existed long enough to give rise to constructive notice, but it does not establish a rule that a “long‑standing, open, and obvious defect” necessarily gives rise to constructive notice and a duty to act. Instead, the court holds that, on the facts presented, the evidence did not warrant an inference that the substance had been present long enough and orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, the opinion is generally restrictive on finding constructive notice and does not affirm the broad proposition stated.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.… The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element.”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, such a long‑standing, open, and obvious defect gives rise to constructive notice and a duty to act.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does address constructive notice based on the condition of a transient substance (melted ice cream) and nearby employee observation opportunities, and it holds that a jury could infer the substance had been present long enough to impose a duty to discover and remove it. However, the proposition as stated refers to a "long‑standing, open, and obvious defect"—language typically used for more permanent defects—and the opinion concerns a temporary spill, not a long-standing or structural defect. Thus the case supports constructive notice from duration and visibility of a transient condition, but not specifically the "long‑standing defect" formulation.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance. … The record shows that the ice cream must have come upon the floor within the period of thirty minutes which elapsed between the time when the plaintiff entered the store and when he left. Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in after the accident as described by the plaintiff.”

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–07 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: A landowner must take into account reasonably foreseeable weather conditions—such as ordinary summer thunderstorms—when assessing risk from dangerous trees and branches.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s duty to secure dangerous instrumentalities (a forklift) and the foreseeability of misuse by intoxicated third parties. It does not involve trees, vegetation, or weather-related risks, nor does it discuss any duty to account for foreseeable weather conditions like thunderstorms. The foreseeability analysis here is about human conduct on the premises, not environmental conditions, so it does not support the specific proposition about dangerous trees and weather.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. The authority had specific procedures for securing the forklifts… The authority was aware that intoxicated seamen frequented the area, and it was also aware that social guests of officers or crew members routinely visited the ships in port. It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition… would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen…”

Kane v. Hartford, 98 Conn. 677, 682 (192.proposition: A landowner must take into account reasonably foreseeable weather conditions—such as ordinary summer thunderstorms—when assessing risk from dangerous trees and branches.
Kane v. Hartford, 98 Conn. 677, 682 (192.case_name: Bristol Baptist Church v. Connecticut Baptist Convention
Kane v. Hartford, 98 Conn. 677, 682 (192.support_reasoning: The opinion in Kane v. Hartford (as quoted) concerns charitable trusts, conditions of reverter, merger of legal and equitable title, and a court’s equitable power to order sale of trust property due to changed circumstances. It does not discuss premises liability, landowners’ duties, trees, branches, or the need to consider reasonably foreseeable weather conditions such as thunderstorms. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition about a landowner’s duty regarding dangerous trees and weather.
Kane v. Hartford, 98 Conn. 677, 682 (192.relevant_excerpt: “Applied to this case, the remedy therein provided authorizes the Superior Court to order the sale of real estate held by a trustee under a trust created by a deed, when, by reason of a change of circumstances since the creation of the trust, the execution of the trust in accordance with the terms of the deed would fail to secure the objects manifestly intended by the grantor.”

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 45–46 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: The natural force of a typical summer storm interacting with a preexisting, negligently maintained, visibly cracked tree branch does not constitute a superseding or exculpatory cause as a matter of law.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with duty and scope-of-risk/proximate cause in the context of a hospital’s alleged negligence in releasing a sedated patient and a police officer’s subsequent, unrelated auto collision. It does not involve natural forces, storms, trees, or superseding causes, nor does it analyze whether a natural force interacting with a negligently maintained condition is or is not a superseding cause. The proposition about a summer storm and a cracked tree branch is unrelated to the issues and reasoning in Leavitt, so this case does not support that stated legal principle.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The hospital also claims that it should not be held liable on a separate, independent ground: the injury to Leavitt was not ‘caused’ by any action on its part. We agree. Leavitt’s injury was not ‘caused’ by the hospital because it falls outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from any negligent conduct that would make the hospital’s alleged misconduct tortious.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Plaintiff’s harm was a reasonably foreseeable result of Defendant’s failure to inspect, maintain, and remedy the hazardous tree branch overhanging a frequently used public sidewalk.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case deals with proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of a parole board’s decision to release a violent prisoner and explicitly holds that the subsequent harm (a shooting eight years later) was not a reasonably foreseeable result of that decision. It does not concern property maintenance, trees, or a landowner’s duty to inspect and remedy hazardous conditions adjacent to a sidewalk. The reasoning actually cuts against expansive notions of foreseeability and proximate cause, so it does not support the proposition about a hazardous tree branch overhanging a public sidewalk.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: "Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978). ... The Commonwealth argues that, even based on a broad reading of the complaint and all of its allegations, the parole board’s decision in 1987 cannot, as a matter of law, be the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ harm that occurred in 1995. We agree..."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all of her injuries and losses, including interest and costs, under Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C (pre‑ and post‑judgment interest).
